content:
It is unlikely to provide the wrap-span">catharsis that many people seem to be expecting

wrap-span">ROBERT wrap-span">MUELLER has concluded his investigation into links and/or co-wrap-span">ordination between President Donald Trump’s electoral campaign and the Russian government. This is a big moment. The special wrap-span">counsel’s wrap-span">probe has already been the wrap-span">downfall of some of Mr Trump’s wrap-span">closest former advisers. Many of the president’s wrap-span">opponents are hoping his final report, now sitting on the desk of wrap-span">Attorney-General William Barr, is about to hook an even bigger fish: the president himself.

Analysis: How to find a way through a forest of wrap-span">scandals

It will take some time for Mr Mueller’s final conclusions to come to light. Mr Barr, who returned to run the Justice Department for the second time last month, is only wrap-span">obliged to wrap-span">divulge the wrap-span">gist of them to Congress, and in his own time. In a letter to the House and wrap-span">Senate justice committees on March 22nd he said he nonetheless hoped to brief them on the report’s “wrap-span">principal conclusions as soon as this weekend”. He added that he would take longer to consider what “other information” he might make available from the report.

In the meantime, Washington, DC is already half-wrap-span">mad with wrap-span">gossip and wrap-span">speculation about Mr Mueller’s findings and Mr Barr’s wrap-span">putative handling of them. The Democrats’ leaders in Congress, wrap-span">Senator wrap-span">Chuck Schumer and Speaker Nancy Pelosi, greeted the news that Mr Mueller’s report had landed by warning the wrap-span">attorney-general not to allow Mr Trump a “wrap-span">sneak wrap-span">preview” of it. (The White House claims not to have seen it yet.) All the main wrap-span">Democratic wrap-span">presidential candidates, including wrap-span">Senators Bernie Sanders and wrap-span">Cory wrap-span">Booker, then urged Mr Barr to make the full report public.

Amid the wrap-span">speculation, a couple of things can be said with certainty.

First, Mr Mueller’s now-completed wrap-span">probe has been very successful. Over the past two years his team has wrap-span">uncovered details of an wrap-span">extrawrap-span">ordinary wrap-span">propaganda and influence campaign by Russian agents to bend the course of the 2016 election in Mr Trump’s favour. It also found that several members of Mr Trump’s campaign had wrap-span">shady communications with people connected to the Russian government—some of whom were probably spies—and then lied about them.

It charged 34 people with over 200 federal crimes, including two dozen Russians, and six Trump advisers. Paul Manafort, the president’s former campaign chairman, was sentenced this month to seven-and-a-half years in prison, for various financial and other crimes. Mr Mueller’s investigation did not look at Russia’s continuing efforts to attack American democracy. Yet it has certainly helped raise America’s defences against them.

Second, despite a wrap-span">relentless attack on Mr Mueller by the president, who branded the wrap-span">probe a “wrap-span">witch-hunt” and wrap-span">slandered its wrap-span">investigators, it appears to have been conducted without political wrap-span">interference. The Justice Department has wrap-span">intimated that Mr Mueller does not intend to issue any further wrap-span">wrap-span">indictment. And in his letter to Congress Mr Barr said Mr Mueller had not been refused permission to take any “wrap-span">proposed action”. Given the fears Mr Trump’s behaviour raised, this is in itself cause for wrap-span">considerable relief.

It may also be worth adding to the wrap-span">speculation a bit—by noting that the president’s wrap-span">opponents could well end up disappointed by Mr Mueller’s conclusions.

It seems likely that a draft version of them is already available in the hundreds of pages of court filings that support the wrap-span">wrap-span">indictments his team has handed out. They wrap-span">underline the painstaking nature of the Mueller wrap-span">probe. They also provide no clear evidence that the Trump team, for all its lies and wrap-span">evasion, illegally participated in the Russian plot. Nor do they point to wrap-span">criminality on the part of the president. 

The final report could contain additional incriminating details about Mr Trump. If, for example, the special wrap-span">counsel was deterred from wrap-span">wrap-span">indicting him only by the Justice Department’s policy of granting wrap-span">immunity to a sitting president, Mr Mueller might be expected to inform Mr Barr of the charges he would otherwise have brought. This is clearly possible. But there is nothing in the available evidence to suggest it is likely.

Even If Mr Mueller did not find evidence of law-breaking by Mr Trump, his critics hope his report might provide lots of evidence of wrap-span">lesser misdemeanours nonetheless. Yet this would also be unlikely. By longstanding wrap-span">convention, wrap-span">prosecutors should not pass judgements on or wrap-span">reveal wrap-span">salacious details about individuals unless they are related to a case they are bringing against them. That is why former FBI Director James Comey’s decision to criticise Hillary Clinton over her wrap-span">email arrangements in 2016—despite the fact that he had found no case for her to answer—was so wrap-span">controversial.

Only a full wrap-span">disclosure of Mr Mueller’s report would settle the matter. The House of Representatives has already voted wrap-span">unanimously that this should happen. Mr Trump has also said he wants the report to be wrap-span">made public. Yet it probably won’t be, because it is not wrap-span">incumbent upon the careful Mr Barr to do so, and for an additional reason that Mr Trump might take comfort from.

The most damaging misbehaviour by the Trump team—and wrap-span">conceivably Mr Trump himself—examined by the special wrap-span">counsel concerned its communications with Russians. Yet this is subject to a continuing counter-intelligence investigation, and therefore most likely to be kept under wraps by Mr Barr. The fact that the wrap-span">attorney-general has a history of taking an wrap-span">expansive view of wrap-span">executive power, which in this wrap-span">hypothetical case could be wrap-span">cited on national security grounds, makes that seem wrap-span">likelier still.

It is fitting that an investigation that has given rise to so much wrap-span">speculation over the past two years should give rise to yet more at its conclusion. Yet there is one other thing that can be said with some certainty. Even if Mr Mueller’s wrap-span">probe has not provided the silver bullet that Mr Trump’s critics wrap-span">crave, it has already done the president wrap-span">tremendous damage.

It has shown that the wrap-span">initial rumours of wrap-span">illicit Russian support for his campaign—which of course Mr Trump denied—grossly wrap-span">underestimated the extent of the Russian operation. It has shown that his campaign had several wrap-span">liars and wrap-span">charlatans, wrap-span">greedy for a favour from any hand, at the wrap-span">helm. And, perhaps most damaging of all, Mr Mueller appears to have wrap-span">unearthed evidence against Mr Trump on other matters, which has in turn helped wrap-span">sparked a proliferating number of additional investigations.

The special wrap-span">counsel is known, for example, to have been cooperating with federal wrap-span">prosecutors from the Southern District of New York, who are investigating the president’s campaign finances and those of his wrap-span">inauguration committee. Mr Trump has already been named by wrap-span">prosecutors as a co-wrap-span">conspirator in a campaign finance wrap-span">violation committed by his former personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, who has been sentenced to three years in prison for it and other offences.

Whatever may be in the Mueller report, it will not be the end of Mr Trump’s legal troubles, in other words. It may barely be the end of the beginning.

对我们来说这是一种净化。
So crisis is created by the book in order to let you experience a  of the salvation.
所以，这本书营造危机,是为了让人体验得到救赎时的感情净化。

ex: n. 吹牛者；江湖医生
adj. 骗人的
eg2: Incapable of moral clarity, he could never quite admit to himself that he was a charlatan and that his scheme was an impossible fiasco.
由于缺乏明确的道德准则，他从来不承认自己是一个江湖骗子以及他的计划是个彻底的失败品。
Logue won't indulge his patient's stuffiness, while Bertie considers Logue a charlatan until a breakthrough moment that involves Hamlet's soliloquy and a recording machine.
洛格不愿纵容他的病人的自负，而伯蒂则一直认为他的医生是一个江湖骗子，直到某个涉及哈姆雷特独白和录音机的突破性契机。
If you are too trusting of the invisible, then you buy that $89 ebook that comes with the promise of instant riches, or you sign up for ear candling, or invest time and money with a .
如果你对这些无形的事物相当信任，那么你可能会花89美元买一个承诺给你一夜暴富的电子书，或报名参加一次耳烛疗法，或跟一个江湖郎中花费你的时间和金钱。

这个研究工具会帮助你收集、组织并适当地引用你在网上发现的任何资源。
The next time you hear someone cite these percentages, listen with a careful ear, for faulty analyses abound.
下次在你听到有人引用这些比例的时候，如果你仔细听，一定能听到错误的分析。

eg2: Maybe that’s why we save those for the ones  to us, like our families.
也许这就是为什么我们保存那些与我们最亲近的东西，例如家庭。
A. Some of my closest friends in the world are still doing this work — not just in Chicago but elsewhere.
这个世界上一些我最要好的朋友还在做这样的工作——不仅仅是在芝加哥，世界各地都有。
To varyingdegrees, we all have secrets which we do not want evenour  friends to learn, but few of us have skeletons in the cupboard.
我们在不同程度上艘有一些甚至连最亲密的朋友也不想让他们知道的秘密，但是却极少有人有橱中骷髅。

ex: adv. 令人信服地；可相信地；想得到地
eg2: But , this scheme could facilitate a fairly simple and straightforward approach to multithreading: A page could have multiple scripts, and the VM could run them in parallel...

, some of them might reduce the badness of death, in some way.
可以想到，某些特征可能会降低其坏处，在某种程度上。

一个最危险的谋反分子，一个我们奉命要特别严加看守的人，这个家伙什么都干得出。
For many observers, the V for Vendetta mask has nothing to do with a Jacobean conspirator or a modern comic-book slash movie.
对于许多观察家来说，V怪客面具与不论是詹姆士一世时期的阴谋家，还是现代的漫画书/电影都无关。

I realize my saying this is controversial and differs from what we hear from mainstream news sources.
我认识到我的说法是有争议的，而且跟我们从主流新闻来源听到的不一样。

由律师代表
the counsel for the defence/prosecution
被告╱原告的律师
defence/prosecuting counsel

法庭接着听取了女死者的父亲所请律师的陈述。
Therapists were brought in to counsel the bereaved.
请了治疗专家来给死者的亲属做心理辅导。
Most experts counsel caution in such cases.
大多数专家建议在这样的情况下要谨慎从事。
He counselled them to give up the plan.
他建议他们放弃此项计划。

ex: vt. 渴望；恳求
vi. 渴望；恳求

你只是渴望这个人。
Sometimes I crave sushi.
有时我渴望寿司。
If I could find exercises I enjoyed then I’d not only want to do them, I’d  doing them.
如果能发现我喜欢的锻炼方式，那么我就不只是想要去做，而是渴望去做。

ex: n. 有罪，犯罪；犯罪行为

wp.double criminality: 双重罪行;双重犯罪原则;双重犯罪

eg2: So, his letters come out of this western land, New Mexico, and a land of , the reform school.
他的信从新墨西哥这片西部的土地而来，还是寄宿学校这种犯罪滋生地。
"This is criminality pure and simple, and it has to be confronted and defeated," Cameron told reporters from outside his residence at 10 Downing Street.
“这是纯粹的又简单的犯罪行为； 我们必须正视它，并打败它”，卡梅伦在唐宁街10号他的官邸外告诉记者。
We had to be prepared to intervene literally family by family and at an early stage, even before any criminality had occurred.
我们必须准备在初期就逐一介入各个问题家庭，甚至早在任何犯罪行为发生之前。

wp.Fair Disclosure: 公平披露;公平信息披露;公平披露制度;信息披露制度
wp.Full Disclosure: 记者的良心;充分披露;全面披露;完全披露
wp.selective disclosure: 选择性披露;选择性信息披露;有选择披露;性的披露
wp.voluntary disclosure: 自愿披露;自愿性信息披露;自愿性披露;自动申报
wp.disclosure requirements: 资料公开的要求;表露要求;资讯揭露的要求
wp.disclosure management: 披露管理;信息公开管理

ex: n. [审计] 披露；揭发；被揭发出来的事情
eg2: So today in the spirit of full , I lay myself bare.
因此，今天为充分的披露，我把自己赤裸裸的放在这儿。
: I have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours.
披露：我并不持有文中所提到的任何股票，在接下来的72小时内也无意参股。
Not only that, the German Institute for  of a risk assessment of new research information: latex condoms during the curing process can generate a carcinogenic substance - N-nitrosamines.
不仅如此，德国发布危险评估的研究机构披露了新的研究数据：乳胶避孕套在硫化过程中可能生成一种致癌物质—亚硝胺。

ex: vt. 泄露；暴露
eg2: The boy promised not to  the whereabouts of the hiding place.
那男孩许诺不泄露隐藏地的所在。
This kind of targeted attack – known as spear-phishing – has become so dangerous because of the amount of information we divulge on the internet.
这样带有目标性的攻击--叫做鱼叉式网路钓鱼--已经变得很危险，因为我们通常会在因特网上泄露大量的信息。
While an individual site may not divulge too much personal information, the aggregate of all this information may reveal more about them than people realize.
一个个人网站可能不会泄露太多的个人信息，但是当这些信息集合在一起，可能泄露的信息已经超出人们的认识。

但警方没有采取行动，因此我们觉得应该由一个对此案可以立即展开调查的独立部门主管这一案件。

ex: vi. 增殖；扩散；激增
vt. 使激增
eg2: Despite the difficulties, investors assume such deals will continue to .
尽管困难重重，投资者认为这种交易仍将继续激增。
“This resolution will give us new tools to impair North Korea’s ability to  and threaten international stability,” DiCarlo said.
迪卡洛说："这项决议将给我们提供新的手段，削弱北韩扩散和威胁国际稳定的能力。"
This discovery could help scientists devise a treatment strategy based on improving ways to rescue the nerve and stem cells from death and help them .
该发现可能帮助科学家设计出一个基于改进挽救神经细胞和干细胞并帮助它们增殖的方法的治疗策略。

ex: n. 宣传；传道总会
eg2: They muted the  campaign later.
后来，他们降低了宣传运动的调子。
I wish they would stop grinding out the same old .
我总是希望他们不要再绞尽脑汁搞那种老调重弹的宣传。
As with almost all propaganda techniques, the subject should attempt to find more information on the topic.
就像面对所有宣传手段一样，接受者应该试图收集关于话题的更多信息。

wp.propose explanation: 提出的解释;建议的说明;提出解释

ex: vt. 建议；打算，计划；求婚
vi. 建议；求婚；打算
eg2: What do you propose we do?
你建议我们做什么?
We propose an early start tomorrow.
我们打算明天早早出发。
That is why in this blog post, I would like to  something to every designer: Why not try to design something every day for one year?
这也是这篇博客发表的原因，我希望建议每一个设计师：为什么不试试一年之中每天都来做点儿设计？

ex: n. 检察官；公诉人；原告律师；控方律师
网络 起诉人；检举人；检查官
eg2: the public/state prosecutor
公诉人；州检察官

ex: adj. 推定的，假定的
eg2: These messages, however, were greeted with alarm by the program's  customers: the educational departments of developing countries.
然而，这种理念得到的是它假定的“客户”——发展中国家的教育部门带有警觉性的欢迎。
The crime is gender-neutral, and contains no age exemption for putative defendants; whether the perpetrator is male or female, 14 or 40, it is still a felony.
这条罪不受性别限制，对假定的被告也没有年龄限制，无论违法者是男性或女性，14岁或者40岁，它还是一条重罪。
Then I divided the number of putative unemployed people in each scenario by the size of the labor force, to get the theoretical unemployment rates.
然后，我将推测的失业工人按照劳动力规模分配到每个方案中，从而得到理论上的失业率。

wp.Relentless flow: 流水无情;落花有意流水无情;落花有意

ex: adj. 无情的；残酷的；不间断的
eg2: In the relentless busyness of modern life,we have lost the rhythym between action and rest.
在这个无情、繁忙的现代生活中，我们已经在工作和休息之间失去了平衡。
So the system has released this relentless innovative energy, but it's out of human control, and every so many years, there's a crisis.
因此，这个制度释放的是一种残酷创新的活力，但它并不受人类的控制，而且每若干年，就要有一次危机。
This is the design philosophy that leads to overstuffed websites that resemble Times Square in their relentless attack on the senses.
就是这种设计哲学导致了类似时代广场这种冗长的网站，给人类感官以无情的打击。

ex: vt. 显示；透露；揭露；泄露

eg2: China’s television programmers are not far behind their Western counterparts in tapping demand for  entertainment.
中国的电视节目制作者在迎合大众娱乐口味上并不比西方制作人差。
In contrast to the staid newspapers such as the Times, the News of the World published  stories about vice prosecutions and police investigations into grisly murders.
和那些像《时代》一样端庄稳重的报纸不同，《世界新闻报》报道的都是些邪恶犯人的艳情故事和警方对变态谋杀的调查始末。
Sure, it’s not as exciting as gushing about your salacious weekend or your neighbor’s annoying habit, but you’ll never have to worry about that information being used against you.
这当然没有八卦你的周末艳遇或者你邻居的怪癖那么好玩，但好处是你绝不用担心你谈论的东西会背叛你。

他们在阴凉的花园角落里闲聊。
Now at least she can choose her customers, and reject any who seem too .
至少现在她可以选择自己的客人，拒绝任何看上去可疑的人。
Most egregiously, these shady real estate deals victimized American Air Force pilots who were stationed in Japan but wanted home sites in the United States.
最为过分的是，这些阴暗的房地产交易危害了驻军在日本但又想要在国内购置房产的美国空军飞行员。

ex: vt. 诽谤；造谣中伤

ex: v. 溜；偷偷地走；偷偷地做；偷带

eg2: I sneaked up the stairs.
我蹑手蹑脚地上了楼。

我们偷偷看了一眼她的日记。

我设法偷偷给他递了张条子。
I managed to sneak him a note.
我设法偷偷给他递了张条子。

趁他们不在屋里，我偷偷拿了一块蛋糕。

你有没有向老师告我的状？

ex: n. 火花；电火花；火星；活力

eg2: A shower of sparks flew up the chimney.
烟囱里飞出无数火星。
sparks from a faulty light switch
漏电的电灯开关发出的火花

汽车发动机中的燃料由火花点燃。

这一提案将引发全国性的抗议浪潮。

噼啪直响、火星飞迸的火

这条法令由拉斯维加斯市理事会全体成员一致通过，它与在公共场所洗澡将被处以轻罪的法令同属一法案。

在解决问题的过程中可能会发现其他问题，她会采取同样的方法面对每个新问题。
Let yourself feel love and passion towards yourself, your life and everything you do then begin to recover,  or discover your true potential.
让自己感受爱和激情正在走进自己、你的生活以及你随后开始恢复、揭示或发现你真正潜力的任何事情。
Pursuing personal growth is a powerful thing. But it should be used to uncover and cultivate a more authentic self.
追求个体发展是一件很强大的事，但是我们应该用其来揭示和培养更真实的自我。

ex: vt. 发掘；揭露，发现；从洞中赶出

当你更深地挖掘，你便是“窃取”你所发掘的了。
Experts hope to  evidence to support theories that Shakespeare wrote many of his most famous works at the property.
专家 们希望能通过这次发掘找到有力证据，证明莎士比亚的许多最著名的作品是在这一居所创作的说法。
I think of the great work in the Middle East, where sensing aerial photography has been able to  ancient archeological sites, ancient roads and ancient trading routes.
我不禁想起在中东地区开展的宏伟工作，遥感航拍摄影技术被用于发掘考古遗址、古道和远古商道。

图 7 和 8 显示了一个此类违背的例子并提供了一个可行的解决方案。
of the act by which it exists would be self-annihilation; and that which is itself nothing can create nothing.
违反它赖以存在的行为，就是自取灭亡，何况根本不存在的东西并不能创造任何东西。

他花了一个晚上的时间把圣诞礼物都包了起来。

单块包装的巧克力

把肉用锡箔裹起来后再烹调。

我用毯子把婴儿裹了起来。

他的脖子上围着一条围巾。

他的双臂紧紧环抱她的腰。

我怎么才能使文本换行呢？

如果文本太长，在显示屏放不下的话，会自动换行。

明年的时装系列仍在保密之中。

Title: Robert Mueller’s report is complete

paperStatistics.title: Robert Mueller’s report is complete
paperStatistics.desc: It is unlikely to provide the catharsis that many people seem to be expecting
